title: No end to war on terror despite ISIS leader's death: Morrison
text:
Prime Minister Scott Morrison has hailed the death of Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, saying it is a significant blow to the jihadist group but does not mark an end to the war on terror.

US President Donald Trump confirmed al-Baghdadi died during a raid by American special forces soldiers at the weekend on his compound in north-western Syria. The terrorist leader detonated a suicide vest, killing himself along with three children used as human shields, after being cornered in a tunnel.

The Situation Room of the White House as US forces close in on Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi's compound. From left: national security adviser Robert O'Brien, Vice President Mike Pence, President Donald Trump. Defence Secretary Mark Esper, Joint Chiefs Chairman Mark Milley and deputy director for Special Operations on the Joint Staff, Marcus Evans. AP

Confirmation al-Baghdadi is dead was welcomed by allies in the fight against Islamic State, including Australia.

"Al-Baghdadi’s death is a significant blow to ISIS and another important step in preventing its revitalisation," Mr Morrison said.

"It is important to remember his death does not represent the end of the campaign to defeat this terrorist group and the extremism it embodies.
description: Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was in charge of a murderous organisation responsible for 'widespread misery and destruction', Scott Morrison says.
